**"Lord of lords and King of kings" (v. 14)**: This is the order in the Greek here (reversed in 19:16). The phrase uses a Hebrew superlative construction and echoes Daniel 2:47 and Deuteronomy 10:17. It directly challenges Roman imperial claims to supreme sovereignty.

verses.text: After these things I saw another angel descending from heaven, having great authority, and the earth was illuminated by his glory.

And he cried out with a mighty voice, saying: "Fallen, fallen is Babylon the great! She has become a dwelling place of demons, a haunt for every unclean spirit, a haunt for every unclean bird, a haunt for every unclean and detested beast,

because all the nations have fallen from the wine of the fury of her sexual immorality, and the kings of the earth committed sexual immorality with her, and the merchants of the earth grew rich from the power of her wanton luxury."
And I heard another voice from heaven saying: "Come out of her, my people, so that you do not share in her sins, and so that you do not receive her plagues;
for her sins have been heaped up as high as heaven, and God has remembered her crimes.
Pay her back as she herself has paid out, and double her portion double according to her deeds; in the cup in which she mixed, mix her a double portion.
To the degree that she glorified herself and lived in wanton luxury, give her that much torment and grief. For in her heart she says, 'I sit as queen; I am no widow, and I will never see grief.'
Therefore in a single day her plagues will come—death and grief and famine—and she will be burned up with fire; for mighty is the Lord God who has judged her."
And the kings of the earth who committed sexual immorality with her and lived in wanton luxury will weep and beat their breasts over her when they see the smoke of her burning,
standing far off because of the fear of her torment, saying, "Alas, alas, the great city, Babylon the mighty city! For in a single hour your judgment has come."
And the merchants of the earth weep and mourn over her, because no one buys their cargo anymore—

cargo of gold and silver, precious stone and pearls, fine linen and purple cloth, silk and scarlet cloth, every kind of citron wood and every article of ivory, every article made of most costly wood, bronze, iron, and marble,
cinnamon and spice, incense and perfume and frankincense, wine and olive oil, fine flour and wheat, cattle and sheep, horses and carriages, and slaves—that is, human souls.
"The ripe fruit your soul craved has gone from you, and all your luxuries and splendors have perished from you, and they will never be found again."
The merchants of these things, who grew rich from her, will stand far off because of the fear of her torment, weeping and mourning,
saying, "Alas, alas, the great city, clothed in fine linen and purple and scarlet, adorned with gold and precious stone and pearl!
For in a single hour such great wealth has been laid waste!" And every ship's captain and everyone who sails from place to place, the sailors and all who make their living from the sea, stood far off
and cried out as they saw the smoke of her burning, saying, "What city was like the great city?"

And they threw dust on their heads and cried out, weeping and mourning, saying, "Alas, alas, the great city, in which all who had ships at sea grew rich from her wealth! For in a single hour she has been laid waste."
"Rejoice over her, O heaven, and you saints and apostles and prophets, for God has rendered judgment against her for you!"
And a mighty angel picked up a stone like a great millstone and hurled it into the sea, saying, "Thus with violence will Babylon the great city be thrown down, and will never be found again.

And the sound of harpists and musicians and flute players and trumpeters will never be heard in you again, and no craftsman of any craft will ever be found in you again, and the sound of the mill will never be heard in you again,

and the light of a lamp will never shine in you again, and the voice of bridegroom and bride will never be heard in you again; for your merchants were the great ones of the earth, for by your sorcery all the nations were led astray,
and in her was found the blood of prophets and saints and all who have been slaughtered on the earth."

chapters.notes:
**"Wanton luxury" (vv. 3, 7, 9)**: The Greek στρῆνος and its verbal form ἐστρηνίασεν denote not merely wealth but arrogant, sensual excess—luxury that flaunts itself. "Wanton luxury" captures both the material abundance and its morally reckless character.

**"Haunt" (v. 2)**: The Greek φυλακή literally means "prison" or "guard post," but when used of animals and spirits inhabiting ruins, it conveys the sense of a place where such creatures lurk or are confined. The repetition of φυλακὴ παντὸς ("haunt for every") three times creates a deliberate litany effect, which I preserved.

**"Heaped up" (v. 5)**: The verb ἐκολλήθησαν means "were joined together" or "adhered"—her sins have stuck to one another, piling up to heaven. This echoes Jeremiah 51:9 (LXX).

**"Slaves—that is, human souls" (v. 13)**: The Greek σωμάτων καὶ ψυχὰς ἀνθρώπων literally reads "bodies and souls of humans." The word σῶμα was commercial terminology for slaves (human "bodies" as cargo). The addition of "souls of humans" is a deliberate intensification—John emphasizes that these are not mere commodities but human beings. My rendering makes this rhetorical move explicit.

**"Double her portion double" (v. 6)**: The phrase διπλώσατε τὰ διπλᾶ is intensifying: "double the double things." Rather than smooth this into "repay double," I retained the emphatic repetition.

**"Beat their breasts" (v. 9)**: The verb κόπτομαι refers to the physical act of striking oneself in mourning, not merely generic lamenting.

**"Alas, alas" (vv. 10, 16, 19)**: The Greek Οὐαὶ οὐαί is an exclamation of grief and horror. "Woe, woe" has become too familiar; "Alas" captures the lamentation without the prophetic-judgment connotation that "woe" sometimes carries in English.

**"Rendered judgment against her for you" (v. 20)**: The Greek ἔκρινεν ὁ θεὸς τὸ κρίμα ὑμῶν ἐξ αὐτῆς is difficult—literally "God has judged your judgment from her." This means God has rendered the verdict that was owed to you, judging her for what she did to you. My rendering attempts to clarify this.

**"Sorcery" (v. 23)**: The Greek φαρμακεία refers to the use of drugs and potions for magical purposes. While "sorcery" is traditional, it accurately captures the first-century meaning of manipulative, deceptive spiritual practices.

verses.text: After these things I heard something like the loud voice of a great multitude in heaven, saying: "Hallelujah! Salvation and glory and power belong to our God,
because his judgments are true and just. He has judged the great prostitute who was corrupting the earth with her sexual immorality, and he has avenged the blood of his servants from her hand."
And a second time they said: "Hallelujah! Her smoke rises to the ages of ages."
And the twenty-four elders and the four living creatures fell down and worshiped God who sits on the throne, saying: "Amen! Hallelujah!"
And a voice came from the throne, saying: "Praise our God, all his servants, those who fear him, the small and the great."

And I heard something like the sound of a great multitude, and like the sound of many waters, and like the sound of mighty thunders, saying: "Hallelujah! For the Lord our God, the Almighty, has begun to reign.
Let us rejoice and exult and give him the glory, because the wedding of the Lamb has come, and his bride has made herself ready.
It was granted to her to clothe herself in fine linen, bright and pure"—for the fine linen is the righteous deeds of the holy ones.
And he says to me: "Write: Blessed are those who have been invited to the wedding feast of the Lamb." And he says to me: "These are the true words of God."

And I fell before his feet to worship him, but he says to me: "See that you do not! I am a fellow servant with you and with your brothers who hold to the testimony of Jesus. Worship God! For the testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy."
Then I saw heaven standing open, and look—a white horse! And the one sitting on it is called Faithful and True, and in righteousness he judges and wages war.
His eyes are a flame of fire, and on his head are many diadems. He has a name written that no one knows except himself,
and he is clothed in a robe dipped in blood, and his name is called the Word of God.
And the armies in heaven were following him on white horses, clothed in fine linen, white and pure.

From his mouth comes a sharp sword, so that with it he may strike down the nations, and he will shepherd them with an iron rod. He treads the winepress of the wine of the fury of the wrath of God the Almighty.
And on his robe and on his thigh he has a name written: King of kings and Lord of lords.
Then I saw an angel standing in the sun, and he cried out with a loud voice, saying to all the birds flying in mid-heaven: "Come, gather for the great feast of God,
to eat the flesh of kings, the flesh of military commanders, the flesh of mighty men, the flesh of horses and their riders, the flesh of all people—both free and slave, both small and great."
And I saw the beast and the kings of the earth and their armies gathered to make war against the one sitting on the horse and against his army.

And the beast was captured, and with it the false prophet who had performed signs in its presence—signs by which he deceived those who had received the mark of the beast and those who worshiped its image. The two of them were thrown alive into the lake of fire that burns with sulfur.
And the rest were killed by the sword of the one sitting on the horse—the sword that came from his mouth—and all the birds were gorged on their flesh.

chapters.notes:
**"Hallelujah" (vv. 1, 3, 4, 6)**: This Hebrew expression (הַלְלוּ יָהּ, "Praise Yah") appears only in this chapter in the entire New Testament—four times. The retention of the untranslated Hebrew rather than rendering it "Praise the Lord" preserves its liturgical foreignness and connects to the Psalms (particularly the Hallel psalms), which first-century readers would have recognized.

**"To the ages of ages" (v. 3)**: Greek εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων is a Hebraism. "Forever and ever" is accurate but loses the specific construction. I chose a more literal rendering to preserve the idiom's texture.

**"Has begun to reign" (v. 6)**: The aorist ἐβασίλευσεν is likely ingressive—marking the commencement of God's reign—rather than simply "reigns" or "has reigned." This captures the eschatological moment: God's kingdom has now been inaugurated.

**"Diadems" (v. 12)**: Greek διαδήματα refers to royal crowns symbolizing sovereignty, distinct from στέφανος (victor's wreath). The rider wears many royal crowns—a contrast to the dragon's seven diadems (12:3) and beast's ten (13:1).

**"Dipped in blood" (v. 13)**: The robe is bloodied before the battle begins, echoing Isaiah 63:1-3 where the divine warrior's garments are stained from treading the winepress of judgment. This is not blood acquired in the coming battle but blood already present.

**"Military commanders" (v. 18)**: Greek χιλιάρχων literally means "commanders of a thousand"—a specific Roman military rank (tribune). "Military commanders" conveys the martial context better than the archaic "captains."

**"Shepherd them with an iron rod" (v. 15)**: The verb ποιμανεῖ means "shepherd" or "rule." I retained "shepherd" because it preserves the ironic pastoral imagery from Psalm 2:9—ruling nations as one would tend sheep, but with an iron instrument.

**"The testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy" (v. 10)**: The genitive Ἰησοῦ is ambiguous—it could mean testimony *about* Jesus, testimony *from* Jesus, or testimony that Jesus himself bore. The ambiguity may be intentional; the translation preserves it.

verses.text: And I saw an angel descending from heaven, holding the key to the abyss and a great chain in his hand.
He seized the dragon—the ancient serpent, who is the Devil and Satan—and bound him for a thousand years.

He threw him into the abyss, and locked and sealed it over him, so that he could no longer lead the nations astray until the thousand years are completed. After this, he must be released for a short time.

And I saw thrones, and those who sat on them were given authority to judge. I also saw the souls of those who had been beheaded because of their testimony about Jesus and because of the word of God—those who had not worshiped the beast or its image and had not received the mark on their forehead or on their hand. They came to life and reigned with the Christ for a thousand years.
The rest of the dead did not come to life until the thousand years were completed. This is the first resurrection.

Blessed and holy is the one who has a share in the first resurrection. Over these the second death holds no power, but they will be priests of God and of the Christ, and will reign with him for a thousand years.
When the thousand years are completed, Satan will be released from his prison
and will go out to lead astray the nations in the four corners of the earth—Gog and Magog—to gather them for battle. Their number is like the sand of the sea.
They marched up across the broad expanse of the earth and surrounded the encampment of the holy ones and the beloved city. But fire came down from heaven and consumed them.
And the devil who led them astray was thrown into the lake of fire and sulfur, where the beast and the false prophet also are, and they will be tormented day and night to the ages of ages.
Then I saw a great white throne and the one seated on it. From his presence earth and heaven fled away, and no place was found for them.

And I saw the dead—the great and the small—standing before the throne, and scrolls were opened. Then another scroll was opened, which is the scroll of life. And the dead were judged by what was written in the scrolls, according to their deeds.
The sea gave up the dead that were in it, and Death and Hades gave up the dead that were in them, and each one was judged according to their deeds.
Then Death and Hades were thrown into the lake of fire. This is the second death—the lake of fire.
And if anyone was not found written in the scroll of life, they were thrown into the lake of fire.

chapters.notes:
**"Abyss" (v. 1, 3)**: Greek ἄβυσσος refers to the primordial deep, connected to the Hebrew תְּהוֹם (tehom) of Genesis 1:2. It represents chaos and is the prison of demonic forces. "Bottomless pit" (KJV) adds an interpretive element not in the Greek.

**"Lead astray" (v. 3, 8, 10)**: Greek πλανάω means to cause to wander, deceive, or lead off the path. I use "lead astray" consistently to capture both the deceptive and directional aspects—Satan causes wandering from truth.

**"Beheaded" (v. 4)**: Greek πεπελεκισμένων specifically means execution by axe (from πέλεκυς, "axe"), the Roman method of capital punishment for citizens. This is more specific than generic "executed."

**"Came to life" (v. 4, 5)**: Greek ἔζησαν (aorist of ζάω) here functions as an ingressive aorist—they entered into life, not merely "lived." This is crucial for understanding the resurrection language.

**"Encampment" (v. 9)**: Greek παρεμβολή is a military term for an army camp, evoking Israel's wilderness encampment. Most translations use "camp," but "encampment" better conveys the organized, military sense.

**"Scrolls" (v. 12)**: Greek βιβλίον referred to scrolls in the first century, not codex books. This maintains historical accuracy.

**"To the ages of ages" (v. 10)**: Greek εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων is a Hebraic superlative construction (like "holy of holies"). "Forever and ever" captures the meaning, but the Greek emphasizes endless duration through multiplication of ages.

**"Death and Hades" (v. 13, 14)**: I retain "Hades" rather than "hell" because ᾅδης refers to the realm of the dead (equivalent to Hebrew Sheol), not the place of punishment. These are personified powers that must surrender their captives for judgment.

**Gog and Magog (v. 8)**: This alludes to Ezekiel 38-39, where Gog is a leader from the land of Magog. Revelation transforms both into names for hostile nations, a development first-century readers familiar with the Septuagint would recognize.

verses.text: And I saw a new heaven and a new earth, for the first heaven and the first earth had passed away, and the sea was no more.
And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, descending out of heaven from God, prepared like a bride adorned for her husband.
And I heard a loud voice from the throne saying: "Look! The dwelling of God is with humanity, and he will dwell among them, and they will be his peoples, and God himself will be with them,
and he will wipe away every tear from their eyes, and death will be no more—neither mourning nor wailing nor pain will be anymore. The former things have passed away."
And the one seated on the throne said, "Look! I am making all things new." And he said, "Write this down, for these words are trustworthy and true."
And he said to me, "It is done. I am the Alpha and the Omega, the beginning and the end. To the one who thirsts I will give freely from the spring of the water of life.
The one who conquers will inherit these things, and I will be his God and he will be my son.

But as for the cowardly and the faithless and the abominable and murderers and the sexually immoral and sorcerers and idolaters and all liars—their portion is in the lake that burns with fire and sulfur, which is the second death."
And one of the seven angels who had the seven bowls full of the seven final plagues came and spoke with me, saying, "Come, I will show you the bride, the wife of the Lamb."
And he carried me away in the Spirit to a great and high mountain, and he showed me the holy city Jerusalem descending out of heaven from God,
having the glory of God. Its radiance was like a most precious stone, like a jasper stone, crystal-clear.
It had a great and high wall with twelve gates, and at the gates twelve angels, and names inscribed on them—the names of the twelve tribes of the sons of Israel:
three gates on the east, three gates on the north, three gates on the south, and three gates on the west.
And the wall of the city had twelve foundations, and on them were the twelve names of the twelve apostles of the Lamb.
And the one speaking with me had a golden measuring rod to measure the city and its gates and its wall.
The city lies foursquare, its length the same as its width. He measured the city with the rod: twelve thousand stadia—its length and width and height are equal.
He also measured its wall: one hundred forty-four cubits by human measurement, which the angel was using.
The wall was built of jasper, and the city was pure gold, like clear glass.
The foundations of the city wall were adorned with every kind of precious stone: the first foundation jasper, the second sapphire, the third chalcedony, the fourth emerald,
the fifth sardonyx, the sixth carnelian, the seventh chrysolite, the eighth beryl, the ninth topaz, the tenth chrysoprase, the eleventh jacinth, the twelfth amethyst.
And the twelve gates were twelve pearls—each gate made from a single pearl. And the main street of the city was pure gold, transparent as glass.
And I saw no temple in it, for the Lord God the Almighty is its temple, and the Lamb.
And the city has no need of the sun or the moon to shine on it, for the glory of God illuminates it, and its lamp is the Lamb.
The nations will walk by its light, and the kings of the earth will bring their glory into it.
Its gates will never be shut by day—and there will be no night there—
and they will bring the glory and the honor of the nations into it.
And nothing profane will ever enter it, nor anyone who practices abomination or falsehood, but only those written in the Lamb's scroll of life.

chapters.notes:
**"Dwelling... dwell" (v. 3)**: The Greek σκηνή (dwelling/tabernacle) and σκηνώσει (will dwell/tent) contain wordplay evoking the wilderness tabernacle and God's presence among Israel. The same verb appears in John 1:14 ("the Word became flesh and dwelt among us"). I preserved the shared root in English.

**"Peoples" (v. 3)**: The SBLGNT has the plural λαοί rather than the singular λαός. This is theologically significant—the new covenant encompasses multiple peoples, not Israel alone.

**"Wailing" (v. 4)**: Greek κραυγή denotes loud crying out or lamentation, stronger than quiet weeping. "Crying" in modern English has become too mild.

**"Cowardly" (v. 8)**: Greek δειλοῖς heads this vice list, referring to those who failed to stand firm under persecution—a pointed warning to John's audience facing Roman pressure. This is not general timidity but apostasy through fear.

**"Sorcerers" (v. 8)**: Greek φαρμάκοις (from φάρμακον, "drug/potion") refers to those practicing magic through potions and spells—a common feature of Greco-Roman religion that early Christians were pressured to participate in.

**"Radiance" (v. 11)**: Greek φωστήρ means a light-bearing body or luminary (used of stars in Philippians 2:15). "Brilliance" or "radiance" better captures this than "light."

**"Foursquare... equal" (v. 16)**: The city is a perfect cube—its length, width, and height are identical. This mirrors the dimensions of the Holy of Holies in Solomon's temple (1 Kings 6:20), indicating that the entire city is now the sacred space where God dwells.

**"By human measurement, which the angel was using" (v. 17)**: This clarifying phrase indicates that the angel employed standard human units of measurement rather than some celestial scale.

**"Profane" (v. 27)**: Greek κοινόν means "common" in the ritual sense—that which is unclean or unholy, the opposite of consecrated. "Unclean" carries too many modern associations; "profane" better captures the cultic sense.

**"Scroll of life" (v. 27)**: Greek βιβλίον refers to a scroll rather than a codex (book). The image is of a registry or census document listing citizens.

verses.text: And he showed me a river of living water, radiant as crystal, flowing from the throne of God and of the Lamb

down the middle of the city's main street. On each side of the river stood the tree of life, producing twelve kinds of fruit, yielding its fruit each month, and the leaves of the tree are for the healing of the nations.
There will no longer be anything accursed. The throne of God and of the Lamb will be in the city, and his servants will render him priestly service.
They will see his face, and his name will be on their foreheads.
Night will be no more, and they will have no need of lamplight or sunlight, because the Lord God will shine upon them, and they will reign unto the ages of the ages.
And he said to me, "These words are trustworthy and true. The Lord, the God of the spirits of the prophets, has sent his angel to show his servants what must soon take place.
And look—I am coming quickly! Blessed is the one who keeps the words of the prophecy of this book."
And I, John, am the one who heard and saw these things. And when I heard and saw, I fell down to worship at the feet of the angel who was showing me these things.
But he says to me, "Do not do that! I am a fellow servant with you and with your brothers the prophets and with those who keep the words of this book. Worship God!"
And he says to me, "Do not seal up the words of the prophecy of this book, for the appointed time is near.
Let the wrongdoer continue doing wrong, and let the filthy continue in filth, and let the righteous continue doing righteousness, and let the holy continue being made holy."
"Look—I am coming quickly, and my wages are with me, to repay each person according to their work.
I am the Alpha and the Omega, the first and the last, the beginning and the end."
Blessed are those who wash their robes, so that they will have the right to the tree of life and may enter the city through its gates.
Outside are the dogs—the sorcerers, the sexually immoral, the murderers, the idol-worshippers, and everyone who loves and practices falsehood.
"I, Jesus, have sent my angel to testify these things to you for the assemblies. I am the root and the descendant of David, the bright morning star."
And the Spirit and the bride say, "Come!" And let the one who hears say, "Come!" And let the one who thirsts come—let the one who desires take the water of life as a gift.
I testify to everyone who hears the words of the prophecy of this book: if anyone adds to them, God will add to that person the plagues written in this book.
And if anyone takes away from the words of this book of prophecy, God will take away that person's share in the tree of life and in the holy city, which are written about in this book.
The one who testifies to these things says, "Yes, I am coming quickly." Amen. Come, Lord Jesus.
The grace of the Lord Jesus be with all.

chapters.notes:
**"Priestly service" (v. 3)**: The Greek λατρεύσουσιν denotes cultic, religious service—the kind of worship offered in a temple. "Serve" in English is too generic; "priestly service" captures that all God's people now perform the sacred function once reserved for priests.

**"Tree of life" (v. 2)**: The singular ξύλον appears on both sides of the river, creating a striking image. This echoes both the Garden of Eden (Genesis 2-3) and Ezekiel's vision of the temple river (Ezekiel 47:12). The singular may suggest one tree of life manifesting on both banks.

**"Unto the ages of the ages" (v. 5)**: The Greek εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων is a Hebraic superlative construction. "Forever and ever" is traditional but flattens the distinctive idiom.

**"Appointed time" (v. 10)**: The Greek καιρός refers to a decisive, appointed moment rather than mere chronological time (χρόνος). This is the critical hour, not just "the time."

**"Dogs" (v. 15)**: In Jewish usage, "dogs" was a term of contempt for those outside the covenant community, particularly Gentiles engaged in impure practices. Here it likely refers to those whose conduct marks them as spiritually impure.

**"Sorcerers" (v. 15)**: The Greek φάρμακοι (from which we get "pharmacy") refers to practitioners of magic who used drugs, potions, and spells. This was associated with manipulation and deception.

**"Adds... will add / takes away... will take away" (vv. 18-19)**: The Greek uses deliberate wordplay: ἐπιθῇ/ἐπιθήσει and ἀφέλῃ/ἀφελεῖ. The punishment mirrors the crime—God will add plagues to adders, remove blessings from those who remove.

**"Wages" (v. 12)**: The Greek μισθός can mean "reward" or "wages." Given the context of repayment according to work (ἔργον), "wages" captures the transactional imagery.
